image.altText: Twenty-year-old Johnson Kokozian wearing a cap looking at the camera and smiling

items.synopsis: NSW Police also confirms two more people had been arrested in relation to the crash.

title.children: Driver accused of killing siblings in Sydney crash has dangerous driving charges upgraded

image.altText: Glen Eira College

items.synopsis: Police believe a group of offenders in their late teens went on a robbing spree, targeting school children from Glen Eira College.

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: The latest GDP data shows an annual slowdown in the Australian economy because of interest rate hikes.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Economy grows by 2.1 per cent in 12 months, Wall Street falls, Australian dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Chief economist at BetaShares, David Bassanese, has just shared his initial take on today's GDP and national accounts figures. He says the results were "stronger than expected" despite the weaker growth in household spending, but it " highlights the tensions that continue to exist between monetary and fiscal policy settings in Australia ". Here's his full take on the figures and their meaning: "National GDP grew by 0.4% in the June quarter, or a touch above the 0.3% gain expected by the market. Over the past twelve months, the economy has posted modestly below trend growth of 2.1%. "Yet within the national accounts, household consumer spending grew by a mere 0.1% in the June quarter, to be up only 1.5% over the past year. Higher interest rates, courtesy of the RBA, are certainly doing their part in slowing down the consumer, which is a big chunk (50%) of the economy. "Higher interest rates, along with ongoing labour and material shortages, have also helped slow housing construction, which fell 0.2% in the quarter and by 1.1% over the past year. "Yet countering this effect has been strength in public demand. In particular, new public investment spending rose by 5.5% in the quarter, which as the ABS notes, reflects "ongoing large-scale transport, health and education projects across a number of states ." Indeed, major public infrastructure programs are also likely contributing to the labour and material shortages in the housing sector — adding to inflationary pressure and "crowding out" much needed growth in housing supply. "While federal and state government commitment to infrastructure programs is usually a welcome development, the present timing of this public investment boom is unfortunate – as it runs contrary to the RBA's efforts to slow the economy and bring down inflation. "All that said, today's stronger than expected GDP report is not expected to change the outlook for the RBA just yet ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Economic growth figures highlight the 'tensions' between monetary and fiscal policy

children.content: Chief economist at BetaShares,
David Bassanese
, has just shared his initial take on today's GDP and national accounts figures.
He says the results were "stronger than expected" despite the weaker growth in household spending, but it "
highlights the tensions that continue to exist between monetary and fiscal policy settings in Australia
Here's his full take on the figures and their meaning:
"National GDP grew by 0.4% in the June quarter, or a touch above the 0.3% gain expected by the market. Over the past twelve months, the economy has posted modestly below trend growth of 2.1%.
"Yet within the national accounts, household consumer spending grew by a mere 0.1% in the June quarter, to be up only 1.5% over the past year.
Higher interest rates, courtesy of the RBA, are certainly doing their part in slowing down the consumer, which is a big chunk (50%) of the economy.
"Higher interest rates, along with ongoing labour and material shortages, have also helped slow housing construction, which fell 0.2% in the quarter and by 1.1% over the past year.
"Yet countering this effect has been
strength in public demand
. In particular, new public investment spending rose by 5.5% in the quarter, which as the ABS notes, reflects
"ongoing large-scale transport, health and education projects across a number of states
." Indeed, major public infrastructure programs are also likely contributing to the labour and material shortages in the housing sector —
adding to inflationary pressure and "crowding out" much needed growth in housing supply
"While federal and state government commitment to infrastructure programs is usually a welcome development,
the present timing of this public investment boom is unfortunate – as it runs contrary to the RBA's efforts to slow the economy and bring down inflation
"All that said, today's stronger than expected GDP report is
not expected to change the outlook for the RBA just yet

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to Brody Viney, a senior economist with NAB, who was speaking on News Channel a little earlier. He said the economy growing by 0.4% in the June quarter was indicative of the impact interest rates and inflation were having, especially on household consumption, which was "broadly flat" and only up 0.1%. Mr Viney also said the figures would be in line with what the RBA was expecting to see. "We also have to remember with the slowing in the economy, it's from a high starting point," he said. "So growth was strong through 2022, so from a high starting point it's natural to get slowing, and then on top of that the RBA is looking for that slowing in demand to show those rate rises that they put through are working to bring a better balance between supply and demand in the economy. "I think broadly these numbers would suggest, and certainly with that soft or broadly flat consumption number for the quarter, that would confirm the rate rises are having the impact the RBA is looking for ." You can watch his full chat with finance presenter Alicia Barry below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: GDP figures show interest rates are 'having the impact the RBA is looking for'

He said the economy growing by 0.4% in the June quarter was indicative of the

Mr Viney also said the figures would be in line with what the RBA was expecting to see.
"We also have to remember with the slowing in the economy, it's from a high starting point," he said.
"So growth was strong through 2022, so from a high starting point it's natural to get slowing, and then on top of that the
RBA is looking for that slowing in demand
to show those rate rises that they put through are working to bring a better balance between supply and demand in the economy.
"I think broadly these numbers would suggest, and certainly with that soft or broadly flat consumption number for the quarter,
that would confirm the rate rises are having the impact the RBA is looking for

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just before he attended a press conference on the GDP figures, Treasurer Jim Chalmers announced Danielle Wood has been appointed as the next boss of the Productivity Commission. Ms Wood is the current chief executive at the Grattan Institute, and has been appointed to the role after Chris Barrett decided against taking the job. She will also be first woman to lead the Productivity Commission. "Ms Wood is an outstanding economist who will bring exceptional public policy expertise to the Productivity Commission, Mr Chalmers said. "Her track record of leadership and innovative research at the Grattan Institute will greatly contribute to the PC's mission." Ms Wood will begin her five-year term "as soon as possible", subject to final approval by the Governor-General. Mr Barrett will instead begin as the Victorian Secretary of the Department of Treasury and Finance in December.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Danielle Wood to be the next chair of the Productivity Commission

children.content: Just before he attended a press conference on the GDP figures,
Treasurer Jim Chalmers
announced
Danielle Wood
has been appointed as the next boss of the
Productivity Commission
Ms Wood is the current chief executive at the
Grattan Institute
, and has been appointed to the role after
Chris Barrett
decided against taking the job.
She will also be
first woman to lead the Productivity Commission
"Ms Wood is an outstanding economist who will bring exceptional public policy expertise to the Productivity Commission, Mr Chalmers said.
"Her track record of leadership and innovative research at the Grattan Institute will greatly contribute to the PC's mission."
Ms Wood will begin her five-year term "as soon as possible", subject to final approval by the Governor-General.
Mr Barrett will instead begin as the Victorian Secretary of the Department of Treasury and Finance in December.

image.altText: A mother and father holding their young daughter between them, smiling. They are standing on an apartment balcony.

image.altText: Vanessa Hudson, the incoming Qantas CEO, with model plane in foreground showing Flying Kangaroo

image.altText: A woman's hands holding two shells, seen from above

image.altText: A small chimpanzee on a rope
